message: I'm always in favour of awesome things.
awesome things are awesome, and this sounds awesome
speaking of awesome, i was wondering whats ep.io stand for?
awesome name btw
It doesn't stand for anything in particular; Ben was just going through available domains at DjangoCon last year, and thought it sounded good.
really was available? 2 letter cctlds are usually reserved by the registry
def ... i'm a stickler for short, sweet names, so i'm one of the few who'd care, .. btw do you limit app names ... e.g bz.ep.io ?
I know, but nic.io are more permissive (will let you have it as long as it's not a country code, IIRC)
makes sense
nice, i like it more than djangy & gondor.io ... if i had to choose on name alone i'd go with ep.io
hopefully, we'll be able to compete on more than name alone
still, the others at least have one obvious pronounciation
we do, there's a set of disallowed regexes
but we'll give out restricted names on a case-by-case basis
we just don't want to let anyone register secure.ep.io
swearwords, server name patterns, anything 3 letters or less
I found myself trying to find the documentation for the deployment awesomeness. You can find it here: http://www.ep.io/docs/requirements/
@citadelgrad you will have to remember to disable the admin media symlink and use your own in /static/media/grappelli
@andrewgodwin I should mention that I registered beta.ep.io. I'm not using it though, so you can blow it away and add it to your regex.

@webmaven Ah, yes - you have no idea how many different things need to go in that list. We're going to have to write some provision into our terms where we can reclaim names (with the obvious caveat that if you ask us if it's alright first and we say yes, we can't).
